iConsole.ads.name: iConsole.ads
iConsole.ads.description:
Adverts
-------
Adverts are controlled by the game_details.json file located in the root of game.

TODO documentation w.r.t. game_details.json configuration

Types
-----
+ 'none' No adverts
+ 'interstitial' Always show ads
+ 'levelStarted' dependant on 'level' numbers defined in the section 
+ 'max_time' displays when 'maxseconds' has expired between calls.
+ 'every_attempt' displays at everyattempt from 'start' count then ever 'between' count

GettingStarted.name: GettingStarted
GettingStarted.description:
Getting Started
---------------
Welcome to the documentation for developing games for the iWin Games Console.

Quick Start
----------- 
To get started quickly please read through the step by step guide here
[https://github.com/iwininc/html5-games-console](https://github.com/iwininc/html5-games-console)

To see some games already in production using the iWin Games Console please visit
- JewelQuest [http://m.iwin.com/game/match3/puzzle-match3-jewelquest]
- S'more Words [http://m.iwin.com/game/puzzle/smorewords]
- Yukon Solitaire [http://m.iwin.com/game/casual/solitairequestklondike]

Notes on Improving Game Performance
-----------------------------------
+ Only load the required assets at startup and load level specific assets as they are needed.
+ Think about using JPEGs rather than PNGs (if you can)
+ Use compressed image file types
+ Reduce the bit rate for audio files.
+ When pre-compiling data structures, consider breaking the computation blocks into smaller chunks and use timed callbacks to step through these chunks. This will ensure that the console gains some of the CPU time to ensure it can update the UI accordingly, and ensure that the browser doesn't consider the process to have died because it hasn't completed the call in a timely manner

iConsole.game.name: iConsole.game
iConsole.game.description:
Game
---------------

As your game loads, you will integrate notification calls to the console to notify it of progress.
Typically this is done when pre-loading assets required for the game.

Once the game assets have been fully loaded, the game will notify the console that the game has finished loading.
The console will do any necessary work, such as dismissing pre-roll advert panels (if configured and after minimum advert duration has been reached).

Additional API calls can then be used.

iConsole.iap.name: iConsole.iap
iConsole.iap.description:
In App Purchases ---------------- The iWin Games Console supports external In App Purchase providers, all accessible through a single API call, which means that as a developer, you only need to write support for In App Purchases in one way, to gain support for multiple providers and any future integrations with other IAP providers will continue to be obfuscated behind this single call. Currently Supported Platforms ----------------------------- * Amazon HTML5 App Store * Games.com * Yahoo Games Network Configuration ------------- You will need to update the game_details.json file, to have an "iap" object at the root, and this should contain a mapping of sku to an object which describes that sku: 
    "iap": {
      "com.iwin.more-time" : {
          "name": "Get More Time",
          "description": "Get More Time",
          "icon": "https://s3-external-1.amazonaws.com/com-amazon-mas-catalog/M1I0LM77RX7FC2%2FM2VC2AJFZBAC93%2Fimages%2F_6b7d1378-12ae-48aa-92e2-618476ab5553_ceb500dbf0e42ce1435155dabebfb8b2",
          "currency": "usd",
          "amount": "0.99",
          "foo": "bar"
      },
      "com.iwin.more-moves" : {
          "name": "Get More Moves",
          "description": "Get More Moves",
          "icon": "https://s3-external-1.amazonaws.com/com-amazon-mas-catalog/M1I0LM77RX7FC2%2FM2VC2AJFZBAC93%2Fimages%2F_6b7d1378-12ae-48aa-92e2-618476ab5553_ceb500dbf0e42ce1435155dabebfb8b2",
          "currency": "usd",
          "amount": "0.99",
          "foo": "bar"
      },
      "com.iwin.more-midas" : {
          "name": "Get More Midas Touches",
          "description": "Get More Midas Touches",
          "icon": "https://s3-external-1.amazonaws.com/com-amazon-mas-catalog/M1I0LM77RX7FC2%2FM2VC2AJFZBAC93%2Fimages%2F_6b7d1378-12ae-48aa-92e2-618476ab5553_ceb500dbf0e42ce1435155dabebfb8b2",
          "currency": "usd",
          "amount": "1.99",
          "foo": "bar"
      },
      "com.iwin.fill-lives" : {
          "name": "Fill Lives",
          "description": "Fill Lives",
          "icon": "https://s3-external-1.amazonaws.com/com-amazon-mas-catalog/M1I0LM77RX7FC2%2FM2VC2AJFZBAC93%2Fimages%2F_6b7d1378-12ae-48aa-92e2-618476ab5553_ceb500dbf0e42ce1435155dabebfb8b2",
          "currency": "usd",
          "amount": "0.99",
          "foo": "bar"
      }
   }
Currently (owing to restrictions from third party providers) the only currency supported is USD, and the amount should be provided as dollar.cents You will also need to create an amazon.sdktester.json file in the root of the released game folder, which reflects the same information (just in an amazon specific manner): 
{
   "com.iwin.game-levels" : {
       "itemType" : "ENTITLED",
       "price" : "0.99",
       "title": "Unlock All Levels",
       "description": "Unlock All Levels",
       "smallIconUrl": "https://s3-external-1.amazonaws.com/com-amazon-mas-catalog/M1I0LM77RX7FC2%2FM2VC2AJFZBAC93%2Fimages%2F_6b7d1378-12ae-48aa-92e2-618476ab5553_ceb500dbf0e42ce1435155dabebfb8b2"
   },
   "com.iwin.more-time" : {
       "itemType" : "CONSUMABLE",
       "price" : "0.99",
       "title": "Get More Time",
       "description": "Get More Time",
       "smallIconUrl": "https://s3-external-1.amazonaws.com/com-amazon-mas-catalog/M1I0LM77RX7FC2%2FM2VC2AJFZBAC93%2Fimages%2F_6b7d1378-12ae-48aa-92e2-618476ab5553_ceb500dbf0e42ce1435155dabebfb8b2"
   },
   "com.iwin.more-moves" : {
       "itemType" : "CONSUMABLE",
       "price" : "0.99",
       "title": "Get More Moves",
       "description": "Get More Moves",
       "smallIconUrl": "https://s3-external-1.amazonaws.com/com-amazon-mas-catalog/M1I0LM77RX7FC2%2FM2VC2AJFZBAC93%2Fimages%2F_6b7d1378-12ae-48aa-92e2-618476ab5553_ceb500dbf0e42ce1435155dabebfb8b2"
   },
   "com.iwin.more-midas" : {
       "itemType" : "CONSUMABLE",
       "price" : "1.99",
       "title": "Get More Midas Touches",
       "description": "Get More Midas Touches",
       "smallIconUrl": "https://s3-external-1.amazonaws.com/com-amazon-mas-catalog/M1I0LM77RX7FC2%2FM2VC2AJFZBAC93%2Fimages%2F_6b7d1378-12ae-48aa-92e2-618476ab5553_ceb500dbf0e42ce1435155dabebfb8b2"
   },
   "com.iwin.fill-lives" : {
       "itemType" : "CONSUMABLE",
       "price" : "0.99",
       "title": "Fill Lives",
       "description": "Fill Lives",
       "smallIconUrl": "https://s3-external-1.amazonaws.com/com-amazon-mas-catalog/M1I0LM77RX7FC2%2FM2VC2AJFZBAC93%2Fimages%2F_6b7d1378-12ae-48aa-92e2-618476ab5553_ceb500dbf0e42ce1435155dabebfb8b2"
   }
}
Integration ----------- The [iConsole.iap](iConsole.iap.html) class is the integration point that developers should use to determine if the IAP platform is supported (i.e. that the game is running on a platform that supports IAP or not), and then to make these purchases. Once the configuration is correct, using the IAP platform is quite simple: 
// Decorate my game differently if IAP is supported
if ( iConsole.iap.isSupported() ) {
   myGame.state.buyMoreLivesEnabled = true;
   myGame.state.buyMoreMovesEnabled = true;
}

/**
 * Handler for Buy More Lives button
 */
function buyMoreLivesClicked() {
   // We don't need to test to see if IAP is supported. If it isn't supported, this call will call the failed block
   // After a short delay (i.e. after a setTimeout of 1ms)
   iConsole.iap.purchase('buymorelivessku')
      .success(purchaseSuccess)
      .failure(purchaseFailure);
}

/**
 * Handler for when a purchase succeeds
 */
function purchaseSuccess(sku) {
   switch (sku) {
      case 'buymorelivessku':
         myGame.state.lives += 5;
         break;
      case 'buymoremovessku':
         myGame.state.moves += 10;
         break;
   }
}
/**
 * Handler for when a purchase fails
 */
function purchaseFailure(sku) {
   console.log('Purchase failed for sku=' + sku );
}
Launching / Testing ------------------- Normally, a console enabled game is launched (on a local development server, with host file entry of 127.0.0.1 local.games.iwin.com) with [http://local.games.iwin.com/#/game/](http://local.games.iwin.com/#/game/) where the folder after the # symbol tells the console where to load the game from. You can append on to this URL, the following * #!amazon to enable Amazon integration * [http://local.games.iwin.com/#/game/#!amazon](http://local.games.iwin.com/#/game/#!amazon) * #!gamescom to enable Games.com integration * [http://local.games.iwin.com/#/game/#!gamescom](http://local.games.iwin.com/#/game/#!gamescom) * #!yahoo to enable Yahoo integration * [http://local.games.iwin.com/#/game/#!yahoo](http://local.games.iwin.com/#/game/#!yahoo) ### Amazon This is the simplest integration to test, as it works out of the box, and does not require any special workarounds or notes. In App Purchases complete when you attempt them without costing real money. ### Games.com The games.com integration requires you to configure a HTML5 game in [http://developer.games.com](http://developer.games.com) and to insert this link (for initial testing purposes) in the externally hosted URL. Also, their In App Purchasing opens up a pop-up window which may be automatically blocked (which means your purchases will fail), so be aware of this issue. When making a purchase, you can use the magic credit card 4444444444444448 (with any other value for the rest of the fields). ### Yahoo You will need to set up an externally hosted Canvas game in the Yahoo development. The remainder of this integration remains undocumented. Further Platform Integration ---------------------------- Beyond In-App-Purchasing, these platforms also offer other services, which are supported by the Console: ### Amazon * amazonmotiongesturetilt - When on a Fire Phone, you can tilt the phone around it's Y axis, which Amazon request is used to hide any menus. This has been exposed in the iConsole as: 
iConsole.game.onEvent('tiltYaxis', function(...){...});
* Home widget label - When the App is installed onto an Amazon device, it has space for a label below the icon on the home screen. Typically, this can be used to provide contextual information about the user's progress in the game, such as which level they are on. This is available as: 
iConsole.game.setHomeWidgetLabel('Continue playing from level 9');
### Games.com * All user data is stored on the Games.com servers rather than the iWin Servers

iConsole.mp.name: iConsole.mp

iConsole.mp.simple.name: iConsole.mp.simple
iConsole.mp.simple.description:
Simple Multiplayer Mode --------------- Within our mobile application, we have the potential to integrate with an asynchronous Multiplayer experience currently partnering with Skillz. This multiplayer experience works such that you can initiate the Multiplayer experience, which loads up the third party UI, allowing the user to join an asynchronous gaming tournament (which could be head to head, or n players, or play as many times in a given time frame to attempt to get the highest score). Once the game has made the choice to work in Multiplayer mode, it must behave differently than normal, in such that the game is not listening to a user input for when the game should start, or what type of level to show the user, but instead listen to callbacks from this API as to when a level should be started. During the progress of a level, the game should regularly report the user's current score (this could be every n seconds, or whenever the score is increased). This is such that it is easier to determine if foul play has come in to effect. Remember that users can and will be playing for REAL MONEY as well as virtual currency. The typical flow would be to: * register the session started callback, to ensure that your game is notified of when the MP experience has determined the user is about to start a tournament * register the exit multiplayer callback, to ensure that the game is aware of what mode it should be working in * Either bind a button to the startMultiplayer (i.e. a Start Multiplayer Mode button on the UI), or if the game is going to launch straight in to Multiplayer mode, to call startMultiplayer when it is fully configured and ready to start listening to the callbacks for the tournament session started. * When the callback to the session started has occurred, you should read the attributes passed in the object to callback function, to determine any configuration needed to be applied. For example a tournament may be configured to disable all collectible powerups, to further increase difficulty. The game session should then begin. * During a game session, if you are playing in a Multiplayer session, you should report regularly the players score, to ensure that foul play can be detected by the third party provider. * Once a game has completed, you should endSession with the users score. At this point the game should be prepared to receive a callback on either the session started callback, or the exiting multiplayer callback * If the game offers the ability, if the user ends their current game, it should call abortSession to notify the third party the player has forfeited their tournament. It should be noted that on the mobile application (but not on the desktop console), the Math.random object will be overridden with a slightly slower implementation. This implementation will ensure that all players in a given ongoing tournament will have the same random seed at the start of their game session. This should mean that all players see the same initial state. Your game should not (unless explicitly required to do so) take any other factors in to account when attempting to use a random number (i.e. don't do Math.random() * 10000 + Date.now() - oldTimeStamp). In the case of a traditional Match 3 game, this should mean that two players with the same seed, should be able to play identical moves and see identical elements on their board at each move. Scoring should not be using any random element, but can use time (to reward faster activity for example). To verify this behavior on a desktop console, append #!mpsimpledebug to the url of the console/game url: http://s.games.iwin.com/m/console/v_217/#/m/iwin/bubble-town-quest/v_117/#!mpsimpledebug This indicates to the console that it should say that the iConsole.mp.simple.isSupported should return true, and allow for debug calls to be made on the Javascript Console. When your game implements the iConsole.mp.simple calls, you will see the javascript console report this: * iConsole.game.exitApplication - "Game has requested to exit the application - unsupported on this client" * iConsole.mp.simple.startMultiplayer - an Alert box will appear on screen * iConsole.mp.simple.reportScore - "Game Score reported as XXX" where XXX is the score * iConsole.mp.simple.abortSession - "User aborted game, returning control to game in 5 seconds time" * iConsole.mp.simple.endSession - "Game finished with score XXX returning control to game in 5 seconds time" where XXX is the score Once you have called iConsole.mp.simple.startMultiplayer from the debug desktop javascript console, two methods are available on the window object: 
// Call this function from the javascript console to pretend to initiate a new Multiplayer Tournament Session
// You can pass in an object which can contain key/value pairs, which will be exposed to the sessionStarted
// callback function
window.startMPSimpleSession( {
    tournamentParam1 : tournamentValue1,
    ...
    tournamentParamN : tournamentValueN
} );

// Call this function to pretend to exit out of the multiplayer experience from the third party.
window.exitMP();

iConsole.periodical.name: iConsole.periodical
iConsole.periodical.description:
Periodical ------- Periodical game data (i.e. daily games) payload handling via the console. Periodical files should be stored in a folder call periodical inside the parent of the game directory... i.e. in the folder beside site-console: + game + periodical + site-console ... When the game is released onto production, this folder sits alongside the versions of the game + periodical + v_72 + v_73 ... Inside the periodical folder, should be a file periodical.json. It should contain in the root of the JSON, an array called "periods", which is an array of objects. Each of these objects should have at least a "name", a "date" in YYYYMMDD format, and a "json" which is a local reference to a given periods actual data file. You can provide further details such as a thumbnail image here, but the data in this file should be kept to a minimum for only information that is necessary to allow the user to choose the period The referenced JSON file should be used to store all the information about what the game needs to present a given periods data. periodical.json: 
{
   "periods": [
		{
           "json": "daily-test-140905-1.json",
			"name": "Test A",
			"date": "20140701"
       },
       {
           "json": "daily-test-140905-2.json",
			"name": "Test B",
			"date": "20140630"
       },
       {
           "json": "daily-test-140905-3.json",
			"name": "Test C",
			"date": "20140629"
       }
   ]
}
The data format for each periods json file is entirely at the games discretion, however, you are strongly recommended to have a "periodical" object at the root of each periods data, and this should include everything you need to represent this game to allow the user to choose that period (for example, the name of the puzzle, a picture of that puzzle etc...). We have a process to take source data and convert this into data suited for long life caching and better user browser performance, and it can automatically generate the parent periodical.json file, and uses the "periodical" block in each periods data to generate the "name" and other data attributes needed. Once you have periodical data, you will need to alter the game_details.json file to have
"periodical": true
set, in order for the console to consider your game a candidate for enabling periodical data (improper setting of this value either results in a volume of 404s, or periodical functions not working). Inside the game, you can call:
iConsole.periodical.getPeriods().result( function( periodData ) {
   // ...
});
Which will return you the basic objects from the periodical.json file, including name and date (and any data you have injected there). You should use this data to allow the user to choose a period to play, and you should obtain an index from this array that the user has chosen. In order to download that data, you should then call:
iConsole.periodical.getData( indexInArrayThatWasChosen ).result( function( data ) {
   // ...
});
If any of your data contains URLs to assets relative to that periods data, such as images, you should call:
var realURItoCall = iConsole.periodical.getFileURI('myImage.jpg');
prior to attempting to load these assets. This ensures that the correct location for these assets are used

classitems.description:
In order to flag an advert to potentially be shown, you call this function with appropriate data blocks as defined below. You should pause your game play and mute any sound/music whilst the advert is displayed. You will be notified via the result callback once the console has completed its advert display process. At this point you should un mute and un pause your game.
If you declare your data type to be interstitial, then the advert (currently) will be triggered always. If you declare your data type to be levelStarted, then the advert may or may not fire based upon the behaviour defined in the game_details.json file. If the advert isn't fired, the result is fired immediately. In this case, any code appearing on lines after this call will be called after the result callback is fired, whereas if the advert is fired, any code appearing on lines after this call will be called before the result is fired. Therefore, you should consider pausing all game execution prior to this call, and leave this as the last call to make.

params.name: data
params.description:
An object which contains either 
{
   type: 'interstitial'
}
to fire interstitial adverts all the time, or: 
{
   type: 'levelStarted',
   level: num
}
where num is the level number as an integer that the user is about to start playing. In this instance the advert display behaviour is guided by the game_details.json file.

return.description:
An object that contains a member function result that you should call with a callback function that will be fired when the advert is dismissed. The format of result function is 
result( callbackFunction );
Where callbackFunction is a function that will be called with a single parameter, an object that currently is empty, when the advert has dismissed.

example:
iConsole.ads.show( {
   type: 'levelStarted',
   level: 3
} ).result( function( resultData ) {
   myGame.startGameTimer();
} );
classitems.name: show

classitems.description:
If your game has been configured to use mid game adverts (adverts that interrupt the users game play), then you should register callbacks to determine when the console is about to show an advert. This will enable you to prepare the game in a paused state, pausing timers, fading screens down, waiting for the user to release their finger or mouse if it is depressed etc... and then notify the console that your game is in a state to safely display adverts without impacting the user. You can register multiple callbacks which will be fired (the order of which is not guaranteed), but one and only one of these callbacks *MUST* fire the 
.result
function.

params.name: callbackFunctionToRegister
params.description:
The function that you want to register to be called when the console is going to display an advert mid game. This function will be called with one parameter, an object which has a 
.result
function that you should call when your game is ready to relinquish control to the console for the advert

params.name: context
params.description:
the value of 
this
that will be applied to the function if necessary.

example:
var myMidGameAdvertStartedCallback = function( request ) {
    this.pause();
    this.fadeDown();
    this.waitForMouseUp(function() {
        request.result();
    });
};
iConsole.ads.registerMidGameAdvertStartedListener( myMidGameAdvertStartedCallback, this );

classitems.description:
If your game has been configured to use mid game adverts, the you should also register callbacks to have the
console notify you that the advert has finished displaying, and that the console has relinquished control
back to the game. This will enable you to display a resume countdown timer, fade the screen back up etc...

params.name: callbackFunctionToRegister
params.description:
The function that you want to register to be called when the
console has relinquished control back to the game after the advert has completed. This function will be
called without any parameters, as there is no need to notify the console that the game is continuing, the
console assumes that once this request has been sent, the game is back in control.

params.name: context
params.description:
the value of 
this
that will be applied to the function if necessary.

example:
var myMidGameAdvertFinishedCallback = function( ) {
    this.startResumeGameCountDownTimers();
    this.fadeUp();
};
iConsole.ads.registerMidGameAdvertFinishedListener( myMidGameAdvertFinishedCallback, this );

classitems.description:
If your game supports mid game adverts, and you are applying these calls across multiple classes (i.e. each
level is contained in a different class), then you should unregister any callbacks that you have made.
Otherwise, the callbacks will be fired against all registered listeners and this may result in undesired
behaviour or complete crashes.

params.name: callbackFunctionToUnregister
params.description:
the previously registered function for
registerMidGameAdvertStartedListener to be unregistered

classitems.description:
If your game supports mid game adverts, and you are applying these calls across multiple classes (i.e. each
level is contained in a different class), then you should unregister any callbacks that you have made.
Otherwise, the callbacks will be fired against all registered listeners and this may result in undesired
behaviour or complete crashes.

params.name: callbackFunctionToUnregister
params.description:
the previously registered function for
registerMidGameAdvertFinishedListener to be unregistered

classitems.description:
This is the first call you need to make in order for the game and the console to start communicating with
each other. This call will return an object that you'll need to register a callback handler with, that will
be triggered after the pre-game advert has dismissed. You will need to prevent game play taking place until
this callback has been triggered, otherwise the game will start playing with an advert sat on top.

params.name: data
params.description:
An object which declares what functions you support. If you support these functions you should declare them as function:true... i.e. 
{ soundOnOff: true }
. If you do not support these functions, then you do not need to declare them, as they are assumed to be unsupported. Allowable values are: * soundOnOff - Your game will register event handlers for soundOn and soundOff and handle appropriately * pauseable - Your game will register event handlers for pause and resume and handle appropriately * restartable - Your game will register event handlers for restart and handle appropriately

return.description:
An object that contains a member function result that you should call with a callback function that will be fired when the advert is dismissed. The format of result function is 
result( callbackFunction );
Where callbackFunction is a function that will be called with a single parameter, an object that contains: * a key user that is an object of the user data * a key console that is an object containing: ** a key type that is the type of console that is running, either app or browser ** a key provider that is the provider handling the console

example:
iConsole.game.ready({
   soundOnOff: true,
   pauseable: true,
   supportedLanguages:
}).result( function( resultData ) {
   myGame.setConsoleType(resultData.console.type);
   mygame.setConsoleProvider(resultData.console.provider);
   myGame.showHomeScreenMenu(resultData.user);
   
} );
classitems.name: ready

classitems.description:
While the game is loading all of it's assets, you should call this frequently to notify the user (via the
pre-game advert progress bar) of the game's loading progress. Typically games will pre-load the image /
audio assets needed for the menu and first level of the game. Games may also use this time to pre-compile any
data blocks that may require a degree of time to complete

params.name: data
params.description:
an object contains mappings to:
progress a floating point number from 0 to 1 that indicates the progress the game is making in preparing the game for presentation ot the user. At 1 (i.e. 100%) the game should be in a state (once the pre-game advert has been dismissed) where the user can play or view a menu screen with no further loading screens.
file a string containing the file asset you are loading, or it can be a debug message to indicate what you are processing. If debug is enabled in the javascript console, the console will log out the game loading percentage and this file name/message

return.description: The return object is not needed.

classitems.name: loadProgress

classitems.description: Once the game has finished loading all of it's assets you should call this method to notify the console that you have completed loading of all game assets and pre-compilation. This is in addition to making an iConsole.game.loadProgress( { progress: 1, file: '' } ); call. This call to iConsole.game.loaded indicates to the console that it should allow the user to dismiss the pre-game advert (once the minimum advert time has passed), or if the maximum advert time has passed to immediately dismiss the pre-game advert. This call will ultimately result in the callback function in iConsole.game.ready to be called.

params.name: data
params.description:
either: 
{
   success: true
}
indicating that the game has successfully loaded, or 
{
   success: false,
   item: 'The item that caused the game to fail loading',
   text: 'Any debug information that may help understand why the game failed to load'
}
indicating that the game failed to load, where item and text are both strings that are used to identify to the console and developer why the game failed to load.

return.description: The return object is not needed.

example:
iConsole.game.loaded( {
   success: false,
   item: 'audio/background_music.mp3',
   text: 'Error fetching file'
} );
classitems.name: loaded

classitems.description: This call should be made prior to starting a level, to obtain any data that the game has previously stored for the level about to be played. This is useful to allow a user to continue game progress where they left off. Examples of this can include fetching the data of a previous level (to indicate what items a user has in their in-game inventory). This is an asynchronous call, as the data may need to be fetched from a back-end server, thus the data is passed into a callback function that you must supply to the result function in the returned object. You should also make a call to iConsole.ads.show with the type set to levelStarted as well, and wait for both callbacks to complete before continuing on with the game. Suggested order would be to call iConsole.ads.show first, and then call iConsole.game.getLevelData to ensure that the user is presented with something that is the game just waiting, and only proceed once both of these functions have triggered their callback functions.

params.name: data
params.description:
{
   level: 
}
where the level number is any integer from -2147483647 to 2147483647 (-2147483648 is specially reserved)

return.description:
An object that contains a member function result that you should call with a callback function that will be fired when the user's level data is returned. The format of result function is 
result( callbackFunction );
Where callbackFunction is a function that will be called with a single parameter, an object that contains a key data that is an object of the users data. Any other data other than the data that may be returned in this object block is deprecated and should not be relied upon.

classitems.name: getLevelData
example:
iConsole.game.getLevelData( { level: 23 } ).result( function ( resultData ) {
   myGame.decipherUsersLevelInformation( resultData.data );
} );

classitems.description:
This call should be made to store progress of a level (typically at the end of a level) via a 2k data string.
This is useful to allow a user to continue game progress where they left off or to restart previously failed
levels. Whilst this may result in a back-end call, this call can be made and no callback function required to
handle the result.

params.name: data
params.description:
{
   level: 
   data: 
}
where the level number is any integer from -2147483647 to 2147483647 (-2147483648 is specially reserved) and the data is a string of up to 2048 characters to store, where the contents of this are freely under the control of the game developer.

return.description: The return object is not required

classitems.name: setLevelData

classitems.description:
This call can be made prior to starting a level or prior to starting a game, to obtain any data that the game
has previously stored for the entire game session and any previous information (such as my best score if the
game wishes to display that inside its UI). This is useful to allow a user to continue game progress where
they left off, for example by storing the current user level. This is an asynchronous call, as the data may
need to be fetched from a back-end server, thus the data is passed into a callback function that you must
supply to the result function in the returned object.

params.name: data
params.description: not used but provided in case of future API changes

return.description:
An object that contains a member function result that you should call with a callback function that will be fired when the user's game data is returned. The format of result function is 
result( callbackFunction );
Where callbackFunction is a function that will be called with a single parameter, an object that contains a key data that is an object of the users data. Any other data other than the data that may be returned in this object block is deprecated and should not be relied upon.

classitems.name: getGameData

classitems.description:
This call should be made to store progress in a game session (typically at the end of a level) via a 2k data
string. This is useful to allow a user to continue game progress where they left off or to restart previously
failed levels. Whilst this may result in a back-end call, this call can be made and no callback function
required to handle the result.

params.name: data
params.description:
{
   data: 
}
where the level number is any integer from -2147483647 to 2147483647 (-2147483648 is specially reserved) and the data is a string of up to 2048 characters to store, where the contents of this are freely under the control of the game developer.

return.description: The return object is not required

classitems.name: setGameData

classitems.description: This call should be made whenever the game wishes to post a high score for the global leaderboards for the user. In the future, the console may cause a dialog to appear to congratulate the user on their achievement and so the game should pause execution until the callback function that should be supplied to the result member function of the returned object has been called. Currently, this will be called immediately.

params.name: data
params.description:
{
   score: 
}
where the score is an integer of the users high score they achieved.

return.description:
An object that contains a member function result that you should call with a callback function that will be fired when the high score has been posted and any console interaction resulting from this has completed. The format of result function is 
result( callbackFunction );
Where callbackFunction is a function that will be called with a single parameter, an object that currently contains no data.

classitems.name: postHighScore

classitems.description:
This function should be called when the user has reached the end of a natural gaming session (i.e. they've
run out of lives and can not continue). Game play should not be allowed to continue until the result callback
function has been called.
classitems.name: gameOver

classitems.description:
The user may generate keydown events when they are typing either in the game or in the console. Where the
user is typing into their chat window, keydown events are going to be triggered that games will erroneously
catch and handle. Therefore, instead of registering keydown handlers inside the game, you should add a
handler to the iConsole instead, which will bubble the keydown events except for when the user is typing into
fields that shouldn't trigger game interaction, such as the chat window.
The currently supported event types are:
* keydown - When a key is pressed down
* signedIn - When a user signs in to the console (used to reload the user data from the console and restart the game)
* signedOut - When a user signs out of the console (used to reload the user data and restart the game)
* tiltYaxis - When a user tilts their amazon fire phone around the Y axis (used to dismiss menus in game)
* soundOff - When the console requests to mute all sounds (the game should store the settings of the user overrides, so that if the sound is already muted, a call to soundOn should revert to the user settings)
* soundOn - When the console requests to unmute all sounds (and where a game supports muting of sound effects and music separately, this should return the sound to the previous settings)
* pause - When the console requests to pause the game, this should bring up the ingame pause menu (unless the game is not in a pause-able state)
* resume - When the console requests to resume paused game play, this should unpause any paused game play (unless the game is not in a paused state)
* restart - Only called if the console has received an iConsole.game.gameOver() call, and signifies that the console wants to do the same effect as the user clicking "Replay". However, if the user has already manually done this, then this should do nothing.
* setlocale - If you support locales, you should consider adding support to iConsole.game.onEvent, with the setlocale event. If the user changes their locale during gaming session (the user may wish to change their supported language, this event will fire, and you should cater for updating the UI accordingly.
See iConsole.game.offEvent
classitems.name: onEvent

params.name: eventType
params.description: currently, the only supported event type is keydown

params.name: callbackFunction
params.description: a callback function that will be called every time the console determines a keydown event that should be passed to the game. It will be supplied with a cut down event object, that contains two member variables which and keyCode and a function stopPropagation that can be used to prevent bubbling of the event within the game (if your game registers multiple handlers to the console).

classitems.description:
The user may generate keydown events when they are typing either in the game or in the console. Where the
user is typing into their chat window, keydown events are going to be triggered that games will erroneously
catch and handle. Therefore, instead of registering keydown handlers inside the game, you should add a
handler to the iConsole instead, which will bubble the keydown events except for when the user is typing into
fields that shouldn't trigger game interaction, such as the chat window. This call will be used to
de-register the keydown handler.
See iConsole.game.onEvent
classitems.name: offEvent

params.name: eventType
params.description: currently, the only supported event type is keydown

params.name: callbackFunction
params.description: the callback function that was previously registered with iConsole.game.onEvent

classitems.description:
This function returns the width of the game inside the console, as window.innerWidth will not work initially
when the game is first loaded as the game's window is hidden from display. This function is especially
useful when trying to determine what resolution of graphics the game should load.
classitems.name: getWidth

classitems.description:
This function returns the height of the game inside the console, as window.innerHeight will not work initially
when the game is first loaded as the game's window is hidden from display. This function is especially
useful when trying to determine what resolution of graphics the game should load.
classitems.name: getHeight

classitems.description:
This function is used to set the label underneath the game's image on Amazon Fire devices (currently), and
is typically used to relay information such as what level the user is going to resume playback from.
classitems.name: setHomeWidgetLabel

params.name: label
params.description: - The label to set, example 'Continue playing from level 5'  or 'Welcome Back Trooper', ...

classitems.description: This function is used to explicitly to hide the console window (the chat and highscore window).
classitems.name: hideConsoleWindow

classitems.description:
This function is used to make a request to the console to allow it to inform the game which locale the user
is expecting to use. The console will make the best guess from the locales you have provided which works best.
The locales should be given in LANGUAGE_COUNTRY format, i.e. en-US (case insensitive), and if the users
language matches, it will use that locale, falling back to the first language provided that supports the users
language (i.e. if the user has fr-CA as their locale, but you only offer fr-FR and fr-MZ, then it will return
fr-FR), and where it cannot find a suitable language, attempts to use en-US if provided, and if that fails
attempts to use, en, and if that fails it uses the first locale you have provided.
If you support locales, you should consider adding support to iConsole.game.onEvent, with the setlocale event.
If the user changes their locale during gaming session (the user may wish to change their supported language,
this event will fire, and you should cater for updating the UI accordingly.

params.name: locales
params.description: - an array of string locales that the game supports. If you are offering multiple sets per language, you should attempt to provide the largest populated language first (i.e. fr_FR over fr_CA). Use the following page as an example http://www.localeplanet.com/icu/

return.description:
An object that contains a member function result that you should call with a callback function that will be fired when the console has selected the most appropriate language. There may be user interaction involved, so this is an asynchronous method. The format of result function is * 
result( callbackFunction );
Where callbackFunction is a function that will be called with a * single parameter, an object that will contain a single key, locale which will be a string

classitems.name: requestLocale
example:
iConsole.game.requestLocale( [ â€˜en_USâ€™, â€™en_GBâ€™, â€™es_USâ€™, â€™fr_FRâ€™, â€™fr_CAâ€™ ] ).result( function( data ){
  myApplication.setLocale( data.locale );
}

classitems.description:
This function is used to indicate the game wishes to exit out of the application entirely. This is
effectively a null operation for the desktop console, but on a mobile application, it will either exit the
game and return to the game selection menu for the multi game application, or in the case of a single game
application, will exit the application entirely. This is typically used in conjunction with the simple
multiplayer mode, where the game only supports multiplayer mode, and the user clicks to exit the multiplayer
experience.
classitems.name: exitApplication

classitems.description: This function should be used to feature detect whether In App Purchasing is available or not.
classitems.name: isSupported

classitems.description:
This function should be used to initiate an In App Purchase from the containing platform. If the sku doesn't
exist in the game_details.json, or in amazon's case, configured on their server this function will call the
failure callback.
classitems.name: purchase

params.name: sku
params.description: The sku item you wish to purchase

return.description:
An object which contains two functions, success and failure, which should each be called
with the function you wish to call when the purchase succeeds or fails. These callbacks will be called with a
single parameter, the sku that was attempted to be purchased. These calls can be directly chained:

classitems.description:
This function should be used to feature detect whether external analytics (like Flurry) should be used for
the game. Note that if your game presents a different experience for an IAP game versus a non-IAP game, you
should store your analytic events accordingly.
classitems.name: isAnalyticsSupported

classitems.description:
This function will return the provider that the console is running under, which can be used to target
different analytics accounts
classitems.name: getConsoleProvider

classitems.description:
This function determines whether mutilplayer support has been enabled.
If you were expecting it to have been enabled check your game_details.json config w.r.t. multiplayer additions.
For most games this will return false.
classitems.name: isSupported

classitems.description: This function allows you to register a callback handler for each tick of game state. Game state is polled every n seconds.

params.name: callback
params.description: The callback function you want to be called back on. The callback will receive a populated object as follows

example:
{
  game_room_id: "...",                                                        //internal id of no use to you as a game developer
  server_time: ...,                                                           //milliseconds since unix epoch
  users: [                                                                    //users who are part of this room
    { id: "...", nickname: "...",  avatar_url: "..." , state: { ... } }       //state is whatever you pass up
    { ... }
    { ... }
  ]
}
classitems.name: registerGetState

classitems.description: This function should be used to initiate a user and assign him to the a Room in the multiplayer service.

return.description:
An object which contains two functions, success and failure, which should each be called
with the function you wish to call when the assignment succeeds or fails. These calls can be directly chained:

classitems.name: autoAssignUserToRoom

classitems.description:
This function should be used to flag that the user has started playing the game at the point where lobby activities
have concluded and the game client feels it has enough users to begin.

params.name: options
params.description:
The method accepts an options object which may be expanded later with behaviours for how
additional users join the game once it has started.

return.description:
An object which contains two functions, success and failure, which should each be called
with the function you wish to call when the assignment succeeds or fails. These calls can be directly chained:

classitems.name: gameStarted

classitems.description: This function should be used to flag that the game client has ended the game for all players.

params.name: options
params.description:
The method accepts an options object which may be expanded later with behaviours that
affect what happens to the user at game end.

return.description:
An object which contains two functions, success and failure, which should each be called
with the function you wish to call when the assignment succeeds or fails. These calls can be directly chained:

classitems.name: gameEnded

classitems.description:
This function should be used to update the current players state - other game clients will be responsible for updating
their own player's state.

params.name: state
params.description:
A small state object representing all the data about the user that other game clients need in order
to display the status of that user, examples include board state in jewel quest, number of questions answered correctly
in a quiz game and so on.

return.description:
An object which contains two functions, success and failure, which should each be called
with the function you wish to call when the assignment succeeds or fails. These calls can be directly chained:

classitems.name: updateState

classitems.description:
This function should be used by the game to set the players lobby state accordingly.
For example a user can be either 'playing'   or   'deciding'.
Most players are 'waiting' when they join a room and remain in this state until the game determines it has enough users to start.
At this point each client should update their user into 'playing' state.
The user stays in this state until the user finishes their game, at which point they should be moved to 'finished' status.
When you show the "play again"   or   "leave room" screen the user should be placed into a 'deciding' status.
This allows users to either play again or leave and prevents the game believing it has the correct number of users
already available to start the game.
Users in the 'finished' or 'deciding' status are still technically in the room and take up a players spot until they leave.
Once a user agrees to play again (or is automatically agreed to play again) they should be set to 'playing' status.

params.name: lobbyState
params.description:
must be either iConsole.mp.LOBBY_STATE_WAITING, iConsole.mp.LOBBY_STATE_PLAYING, iConsole.mp.LOBBY_STATE_FINISHED,
iConsole.mp.LOBBY_STATE_DECIDING

return.description:
An object which contains two functions, success and failure, which should each be called
with the function you wish to call when the assignment succeeds or fails. These calls can be directly chained:

classitems.name: updateUsersLobbyState

classitems.description:
This function accepts the users passed to the  getState  callback handler and returns the current player's object.
You should check this response for null - which signifies that the current user could not be located.

params.name: allUsers
params.description: an Array containing all the users

params.name: voyeurUsers
params.description: an Array containg all the voyeur users

return.description: An object representing the user

example:
{
       id: "...",                     //unique id to identify the user
       nickname: "...",               //the nickname of a logged in user or Player#
       avatar_url: "...",             //the avatar url of a logged in user
       state: { score: 34 },          //state is whatever you pass up
       type: "real",                  //type can be real, guest, voyeur
       lobby_state: "waiting"         //lobby states can be waiting, playing, finished, deciding
    }
classitems.name: getCurrentPlayer

classitems.description:
This function accepts the users passed to the  getState  callback handler and returns the other player objects.
You should check this response for being empty.
Note the current user will never appear in this list...
Also note that when users leave a room at any point, they will not appear in the list returned here.
The game clients should keep track of which players were playing and their last recorded state and compare that with the list of players still playing.

params.name: allUsers
params.description: an Array containing all the users

return.description: An array containing user objects

example:
[                            //other users who are part of this room
    {
       id: "...",                     //unique id to identify the user
       nickname: "...",               //the nickname of a logged in user or Player#
       avatar_url: "...",             //the avatar url of a logged in user
       state: { score: 34 },          //state is whatever you pass up
       type: "real",                  //type can be real, guest, voyeur
       lobby_state: "waiting"         //lobby states can be waiting, playing, finished, deciding
    },
    { ... },
    { ... }
  ]
classitems.name: getOtherPlayers

classitems.description: This function accepts the users passed to the  getState  callback handler and returns the users waiting.

params.name: allUsers
params.description: an Array containing all the users

return.description: An array containing user objects

classitems.name: getWaitingUsers

classitems.description: This function accepts the users passed to the  getState  callback handler and returns the users playing.

params.name: allUsers
params.description: an Array containing all the users

return.description: An array containing user objects

classitems.name: getPlayingUsers

classitems.description: This function accepts the users passed to the  getState  callback handler and returns the users finished playing.

params.name: allUsers
params.description: an Array containing all the users

return.description: An array containing user objects

classitems.name: getFinishedUsers

classitems.description:
This function accepts the users passed to the  getState  callback handler and returns the users deciding,
i.e. still in the room but not yet agreed to play again.

params.name: allUsers
params.description: an Array containing all the users

return.description: An array containing user objects

classitems.name: getDecidingUsers

classitems.description:
This function allows the game to show a button to allow the user to leave the game at any point in time.
When called it will remove the user from the game.

return.description:
An object which contains two functions, success and failure, which should each be called
with the function you wish to call when the assignment succeeds or fails. These calls can be directly chained:

classitems.name: userLeftRoom

classitems.description: This function allows the game to show a button to allow the user to be added to a Room of his selection.

params.name: gameRoomId
params.description: the id of the room where the user is going to be added in

return.description:
An object which contains two functions, success and failure, which should each be called
with the function you wish to call when the assignment succeeds or fails. These calls can be directly chained:

classitems.name: addUserToRoom

classitems.description: This function allows the game to get a list of all the available rooms for the current game.

return.description:
An object which contains two functions, success and failure, which should each be called
with the function you wish to call when the assignment succeeds or fails. These calls can be directly chained.
The success function requires a parameter where the rooms will be returned.

classitems.name: getAvailableRooms

classitems.description: This function allows the game to create a new empty room.

return.description:
An object which contains two functions, success and failure, which should each be called
with the function you wish to call when the assignment succeeds or fails. These calls can be directly chained.
The success function requires a parameter where the room created will be returned.

classitems.name: createRoom

classitems.description: This asynchronous call should be made to feature flip your game into which mode it should operate in.

return.description:
An object that contains a member function result that you should call with a callback function that will be fired shortly after this call. The format of result function is 
result( callbackFunction );
Where callbackFunction is a function that will be called with a single parameter, a boolean that will determine if Simple Multiplayer is supported or not.

example:
iConsole.mp.simple.isSupported().result( function( supported ) {
   if ( supported ) {
     myGame.setUpForMultiPlayer();
   } else {
     myGame.setUpForSinglePlayer();
   }
} );
classitems.name: isSupported

classitems.description:
Register a single callback function that should be called whenever the Multiplayer experience launches a
new Tournament session, and requires the game to configure itself accordingly, and then start playing the
game.

params.name: callback

example:
iConsole.mp.simple.registerSessionStartedCallback( function( tournamentData ) {
   myGame.resetGameBoard();
   myGame.configureGameBoardForMultiplayer( tournamentData );
   myGame.startGameSession();
} );
classitems.name: registerSessionStartedCallback

classitems.description:
Register a single callback function that should be called whenever the Multiplayer experience exits. This
is typically done by a user action declaring through the third party, that they no longer wish to play
the current game in Multiplayer mode. If your game supports both modes of operation, you should return to
either a single player mode, or a menu allowing the user to choose the type of play they want to do

params.name: callback
params.description:
The callback function that will be called every time the Multiplayer
experience wants to exit out of Multiplayer mode.

example:
iConsole.mp.simple.registerExitMultiplayerCallback( function() {
   // Game supports Single Player mode
   myGame.resetToSinglePlayerMode();
} );

iConsole.mp.simple.registerExitMultiplayerCallback( function() {
   // Game doesn't support Single Player mode
   iConsole.game.exitApplication();
} );
classitems.name: registerExitMultiplayerCallback

classitems.description:
This function will launch the Multiplayer Experience, and launch the UI from the third party, which
handles virtual currency, tournament matching, user identity and launching etc. It should only be called
once you have registered your callbacks for session starting and exiting multiplayer mode. An example of
when you would call this would either be as the result of a user clicking on a "Play Multiplayer" button,
or as part of the game launching process when the game doesn't support Single Player.
classitems.name: startMultiplayer

classitems.description:
This function should be called periodically by the game, when you are in a multiplayer gaming session,
to update the third party with the user's current score.

params.name: score
params.description: - the numeric score of the user

example:
myGame.updateScore = function(score) {
    myGame.ui.refreshScore(score);
    myGame.ui.animateProgressInLevel(score);
    if (myGame.mpInProgress) {
        iConsole.mp.simple.reportScore(score);
    }
}
classitems.name: reportScore

classitems.description:
This function should be called when the user has voluntarily exited out of the current game (i.e. give
up). The game should expect to receive a callback on either the session started or exiting out of
multiplayer at some point after this call, when the user decides to either start a new game, or leave
the multiplayer experience altogether.
example:
myGame.abortLevel = function() {
    myGame.ui.showSadAnimation();
    if (myGame.mpInProgress) {
        myGame.mpInProgress = false;
        iConsole.mp.simple.abortSession();
    }
}
classitems.name: abortSession

classitems.description:
This function should be called when the user has reached the end of their game session. The game should
expect to receive a callback on either the session started or exiting out of multiplayer at some point
after this call, when the user decides to either start a new game, or leave the multiplayer experience
altogether.

params.name: score
params.description: - the numeric score of the user

example:
myGame.completeLevel = function(score) {
    myGame.ui.showCongratulationsAnimation();
    if (myGame.mpInProgress) {
        myGame.mpInProgress = false;
        iConsole.mp.simple.endSession(score);
    }
}
classitems.name: endSession

classitems.description:
This asynchronous call can be used to determine if you are currently in a session. It is added more as a
helper function, as this is an asynchronous call, and will involve a degree of computational churn which
should be avoided if possible.

return.description:
An object that contains a member function result that you should call with a callback function that will be fired shortly after this call. The format of result function is 
result( callbackFunction );
Where callbackFunction is a function that will be called with a single parameter, a boolean that will determine if a multiplayer session is in play or not.

example:
iConsole.mp.simple.inSession().result( function( inSession ) {
   if ( inSession ) {
     myGame.mpInProgress = true;
   } else {
     myGame.mpInProgress = false;
   }
} );
classitems.name: inSession

classitems.description:
This function should be used to fetch the data for a given number of periods back. This will return exactly
the data as it has been stored in the JSON block (but this data may have been modified with filenames being
changed to support better caching). The data once loaded is called back in the .result(callback) callback
function.
classitems.name: getData

classitems.description:
This function should be used to fetch the total number of periods of data supported, and any data that is
necessary to display these periodicals, such as thumbnails. The data once obtained, is called back in the
.result(callback) callback function.
classitems.name: getPeriods

classitems.description:
If there are any assets which are referenced by the given periodical data, this will not be under the same
directory as the game, and this function should be called to convert a given URI you wish to obtain into a
URI that can be reached. This should be done for every URL referenced by the periodical data, that is meant
to be local to the JSON file.
classitems.name: getFileURI

classitems.description:
This method should be called to explicitly request a login to facebook. The result function that is
returned will be called with a value of either the user ID of who logged in, or null if the user isn't
logged in. If the user is already logged in, they won't be presented with a login dialog.
NOTE
In the desktop console, this will request a login, but the callback will no later than 15 seconds after
calling, as there is no way through our current integration to determine exactly if / when a user has
signed in through this call.
classitems.name: requestLogin

return.description:
An object that contains a member function result that you should call with a callback function that will be fired when facebook has responded. The format of result function is * 
result( callbackFunction );
Where callbackFunction is a function that will be called with a * single parameter, the user's facebook ID or null if not logged in

example:
iConsole.social.facebook.requestLogin().result( function( userID ) {
    if ( userID ) {
        myGame.recordSignedIn( userID );
    } else {
        myGame.restartLevel();
    }
});

classitems.description:
Request a share dialog is opened to share the current game/application. Games running in the normal
console should not (currently) make this call, as the URL that will be shared will not allow the game to
launch. However, games running in exclusive mode in a dedicated app should make this call.
classitems.name: requestShare

params.name: data
params.description:
An object which must contain a key pair for 'message', the message you want to share with
users who are playing

return.description: An object that contains a member function result that you should call with a callback function that will be fired when facebook has responded. This callback function will be called with a single parameter, which will be an object with a success value of either true or false.

example:
iConsole.social.facebook.requestShare( { message : 'Come play our awesome game' } ).result( function( data ) {
    if (data.success) {
        myGame.thankUserForSharing();
    } else {
        myGame.restartLevel();
    }
});

warnings.message: replacing incorrect tag: returns with return
replacing incorrect tag: returns with return
replacing incorrect tag: returns with return

Missing item type If your game has been configured to use mid game adverts (adverts that interrupt the users game play), then you should register callbacks to determine when the console is about to show an advert. This will enable you to prepare the game in a paused state, pausing timers, fading screens down, waiting for the user to release their finger or mouse if it is depressed etc... and then notify the console that your game is in a state to safely display adverts without impacting the user. You can register multiple callbacks which will be fired (the order of which is not guaranteed), but one and only one of these callbacks *MUST* fire the 
.result
function.

Missing item type
If your game has been configured to use mid game adverts, the you should also register callbacks to have the
console notify you that the advert has finished displaying, and that the console has relinquished control
back to the game. This will enable you to display a resume countdown timer, fade the screen back up etc...

Missing item type
If your game supports mid game adverts, and you are applying these calls across multiple classes (i.e. each
level is contained in a different class), then you should unregister any callbacks that you have made.
Otherwise, the callbacks will be fired against all registered listeners and this may result in undesired
behaviour or complete crashes.

Missing item type
If your game supports mid game adverts, and you are applying these calls across multiple classes (i.e. each
level is contained in a different class), then you should unregister any callbacks that you have made.
Otherwise, the callbacks will be fired against all registered listeners and this may result in undesired
behaviour or complete crashes.
